elements.content: Four novel cobalt(II) coordination polymers [Co2(OA)(dib)2(H2O)] (1), [Co2(OA)(bbi)2]·3H2O (2), [Co3(HOA)2(bpe)2(H2O)6]·2H2O (3), and [Co2(OA)(dpe)(H2O)2] (4) were obtained by hydrothermal reactions of Co(NO3)2·6H2O with 3,3′,4,4′-oxidiphthalic acid (H4OA) and corresponding N-donor ligands, namely, 1,4-di(1-imidazolyl)benzene (dib), 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole) (bbi), 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpe), and 1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene (dpe), respectively. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 1 is a two-dimensional (2D) network containing infinite -(Co–O–C–O) n - chains, while 2 features a 2D double-layered structure with two types of homochiral helical chains filled in the cavities. Complex 3 is a three-dimensional (3D) framework with (64.82)(66) topology containing infinite 2D networks pillared by bpe bridging ligands. 4 is a (44.66) topological 3D framework with coordinated dpe molecules occupied in the channels. The results revealed that the flexible multi-carboxylate and N-donor auxiliary ligands are effective building blocks in constructing coordination polymers with diverse architectures. In addition, the magnetic properties of 1, 3, and 4 were investigated, and the results showed that weak ferromagnetic interactions occurred between Co(II) ions in 1 and 3, while 4 displays a weak antiferromagnetic behavior.

In addition, the magnetic properties of 1, 3, and 4 were investigated, and the results showed that weak ferromagnetic interactions occurred between Co(II) ions in 1 and 3, while 4 displays a weak antiferromagnetic behavior.

elements.content:
Four novel cobalt(II) coordination polymers with multicarboxylic acid and varied N-donor bridging ligands were found to show diverse structures, and their magnetic behavior was investigated.

Introduction

In recent years, the rational design and assembly of coordination polymers is a rapid growth field in crystal engineering due to their fascinating structural diversities as well as their potential applications in magnetism, gas adsorption, catalysis, photoactive materials, and so on. However, it is still a challenge to now to control the final products because many factors, such as the coordination geometry of the central metal ions, connection modes of organic ligands as well as the synthetic conditions, have a great influence on the structure of the resulting complexes. According to previous studies, organic ligands play an important role in directing the final structure and properties. Compared to rigid carboxylate containing ligands, flexible multi-carboxylate ligands are of special interest because their varied coordination modes, abundant structural motifs, and flexible molecular backbones can lead to a variety of coordination polymers with appealing structures and related functions. For example, various coordination polymers with intriguing topologies were obtained by reactions of corresponding metal salts with flexible ligands such as tris(2-carboxyethyl)isocyanurate (tciH3), 4,4′-oxybis(benzoate) (oba), and 2,2′,3,3′-thiodiphthalic acid (H4tdpa). According to our previous studies and other related reports, coordination polymers were constructed by using a V-shaped tetra-carboxylate ligand, namely, 3,3′,4,4′-oxidiphthalic acid (H4OA), which exhibits varied coordination modes resulting from complete or partial deprotonated forms, as well as the flexibility around the central O atom. The results revealed that H4OA is a good building block for construction of diverse polymeric structures and needs further investigation. On the other hand, mixed ligands with N-donor groups acting as ancillary connectors have been proven to be effective building units to construct novel coordination polymers because they have strong coordination affinity and can satisfy the geometric need of metal centers.

Introduction

However, it is still a challenge to now to control the final products because many factors, such as the coordination geometry of the central metal ions, connection modes of organic ligands as well as the synthetic conditions, have a great influence on the structure of the resulting complexes. According to previous studies, organic ligands play an important role in directing the final structure and properties. Compared to rigid carboxylate containing ligands, flexible multi-carboxylate ligands are of special interest because their varied coordination modes, abundant structural motifs, and flexible molecular backbones can lead to a variety of coordination polymers with appealing structures and related functions. For example, various coordination polymers with intriguing topologies were obtained by reactions of corresponding metal salts with flexible ligands such as tris(2-carboxyethyl)isocyanurate (tciH3), 4,4'-oxybis(benzoate) (oba), and 2,2',3,3'-thiodiphthalic acid (H4tdpa). According to our previous studies and other related reports, coordination polymers were constructed by using a V-shaped tetra-carboxylate ligand, namely, 3,3',4,4'-oxidiphthalic acid (H4OA), which exhibits varied coordination modes resulting from complete or partial deprotonated forms, as well as the flexibility around the central O atom. elements.content: Furthermore, from the standpoint of property investigation, copper(II), cobalt(II), manganese(II), and other metal ions with unpaired electrons are often employed in crystal engineering in order to explore their magnetic properties. Meanwhile, it is noteworthy that carboxylate groups can exhibit a great advantage in affecting magnetic exchange pathways owing to their coordination varieties. In this case, in order to further investigate the influence of organic ligands on the coordination architectures and related magnetic properties, reactions of cobalt(II) salt with flexible 3,3′,4,4′-oxidiphthalic acid (H4OA) (Scheme ) together with different N-donor ligands were carried out. Herein we report the syntheses, crystal structures, and magnetic properties of novel Co(II) coordination polymers, i.e., [Co2(OA)(dib)2(H2O)] (1), [Co2(OA)(bbi)2]·3H2O (2), [Co3(HOA)2(bpe)2(H2O)6]·2H2O (3), and [Co2(OA)(dpe)(H2O)2] (4) [dib = 1,4-di(1-imidazolyl)benzene, bbi = 1,1′-(1,4-butanediyl)-bis(imidazole), bpe = 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane, dpe =1,2-di(4-pyridyl)ethylene].

elements.content: All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. Solvents were purified according to the standard methods. The ligands H4OA, dib, and bbi were prepared as reported previously. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were made on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker model Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr disks. Power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen gas with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. Magnetic measurements for complexes 1, 3, and 4 in the range of 1.8–300 K were performed on a MPMS-SQUID magnetometer at a field of 2000 Oe on crystalline samples in the temperature settle mode. The diamagnetic contributions of the samples were corrected by using Pascal’s constants.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

All commercially available chemicals are of reagent grade and were used as received without further purification. Solvents were purified according to the standard methods. The ligands H4OA, dib, and bbi were prepared as reported previously. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were made on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer at the analysis center of Nanjing University. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker model Vector22 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr disks. Power X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-6000 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) radiation at room temperature. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under nitrogen gas with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Magnetic measurements for complexes 1, 3, and 4 in the range of 1.8-300 K were performed on a MPMS-SQUID magnetometer at a field of 2000 Oe on crystalline samples in the temperature settle mode. The diamagnetic contributions of the samples were corrected by using Pascal's constants.

elements.content: A mixture containing Co(NO3)2·6H2O (58.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), H4OA (34.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), dib (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and NaOH (16.0 mg, 0.4 mmol) dissolved in 8 mL of H2O was sealed in a 16 mL Teflon lined stainless steel container and heated at 140 °C for 3 days. Pink block crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol several times with a yield of 76%. Anal. Calcd. for C40H28Co2N8O10: C 53.47; H 3.14; N 12.47; found: C 53.38; H 3.26; N 12.43%. elements.content: The crystallographic data collections for 1 and 2 were carried out on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID Imaging Plate diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71075 Å) at 200 K using the ω-scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR92 and expanded using Fourier techniques. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All calculations were performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package except for the refinement, which was performed using SHELXL-97. The data collections for 3 and 4 were carried out on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K using the ω-scan technique. The data were integrated by using the SAINT program, which also did the intensity correction for Lorentz and polarization effect. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS-97, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. Atoms C9, C10, C11, C12, C13, C14, C16, O5, O8, and O9 in 3 disordered into two positions with a site occupancy factor of 0.726(4) and 0.274(4), respectively. The hydrogen atoms of organic ligands in 1–4 were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. The hydrogen atom (H8) of the non-deprotonated carboxylic acid in 3 and the ones of water molecules in 1–4 except for those of O10, O11 in 2 and O5W in 3 were found in the differential Fourier map and located. The positions were refined using fixed isotropic thermal factor referred to the adjacent oxygen atom. The hydrogen atoms of O10, O11 in 2 and O5W in 3 could not be found in the Fourier map and thus were not located. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement for complexes are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations are listed in Table . Further details are provided in the .

Crystallography

The crystallographic data collections for 1 and 2 were carried out on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID Imaging Plate diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71075 Å) at 200 K using the ω-scan technique. The structures were solved by direct methods using SIR92 and expanded using Fourier techniques. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All calculations were performed using the CrystalStructure crystallographic software package except for the refinement, which was performed using SHELXL-97. The data collections for 3 and 4 were carried out on a Bruker Smart Apex CCD with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K using the ω-scan technique. The data were integrated by using the SAINT program, which also did the intensity correction for Lorentz and polarization effect. An empirical absorption correction was applied using the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods using the program SHELXS-97, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXL-97 crystallographic software package. Atoms C9, C10, C11, C12, C13, C14, C16, O5, O8, and O9 in 3 disordered into two positions with a site occupancy factor of 0.726(4) and 0.274(4), respectively. The hydrogen atoms of organic ligands in 1-4 were generated geometrically and refined isotropically using the riding model. The hydrogen atom (H8) of the non-deprotonated carboxylic acid in 3 and the ones of water molecules in 1-4 except for those of O10, O11 in 2 and O5W in 3 were found in the differential Fourier map and located. The positions were refined using fixed isotropic thermal factor referred to the adjacent oxygen atom. The hydrogen atoms of O10, O11 in 2 and O5W in 3 could not be found in the Fourier map and thus were not located. The details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement for complexes are summarized in Table , and selected bond lengths and angles with their estimated standard deviations are listed in Table . The reactions of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, H4OA, and N-donor ligands resulted in formation of precipitates by common methods. Therefore, the hydrothermal method, which has been proven to be one of the most powerful tools in the construction of high-dimensional coordination polymers, was employed in this work. As a result, single crystals of 1–4 suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained. In addition, NaOH was used to neutralize the 3,3′,4,4′-oxidiphthalic acid (H4OA). At first, a molar ratio of 4:1 between NaOH and H4OA was used for preparation of 1–4, and it is interesting to find out that the 3′-carboxylate group in 3 remained un-deprotonated and is free of coordination, while those in 1, 2, and 4 were completely deprotonated. Taking account of this, the amount of NaOH used for preparation of 3 was increased to 5- or 6-fold of H4OA, by which we aim to obtain a product with complete deprotonation of all carboxylate groups. However, the results showed that only homogeneous product with protonated 3′-carboxylate can be obtained by the same hydrothermal process. We assume that several factors together with the reaction pH directed the final structure, such as the existence of N-donor ligand, the thermodynamic and kinetic equilibrium, and so on. The purity of bulky samples of 1–4 was confirmed by PXRD measurements ().
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses of the Complexes

The reactions of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, H4OA, and N-donor ligands resulted in formation of precipitates by common methods. Therefore, the hydrothermal method, which has been proven to be one of the most powerful tools in the construction of high-dimensional coordination polymers, was employed in this work. As a result, single crystals of 1-4 suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained. In addition, NaOH was used to neutralize the 3,3',4,4'-oxidiphthalic acid (H4OA). At first, a molar ratio of 4:1 between NaOH and H4OA was used for preparation of 1-4, and it is interesting to find out that the 3'-carboxylate group in 3 remained un-deprotonated and is free of coordination, while those in 1, 2, and 4 were completely deprotonated. Taking account of this, the amount of NaOH used for preparation of 3 was increased to 5- or 6-fold of H4OA, by which we aim to obtain a product with complete deprotonation of all carboxylate groups. However, the results showed that only homogeneous product with protonated 3'-carboxylate can be obtained by the same hydrothermal process. We assume that several factors together with the reaction pH directed the final structure, such as the existence of N-donor ligand, the thermodynamic and kinetic equilibrium, and so on. The purity of bulky samples of 1-4 was confirmed by PXRD measurements ().

elements.content: Complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group. As shown in Figure a, there are two unique Co(II) atoms in the asymmetric unit of 1. Co1 sitting on an inversion center is six-coordinated with slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry by four O atoms (O3 and O4, O3A and O4A) from two different OA4– ligands and two N atoms (N42B and N42C) from two dib ligands, while the Co2 atom is five-coordinated and resides in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment. Two O atoms (O5 and O5D) from OA4– and O6 from a coordinated water molecule form the equatorial plane, and the axial positions are occupied by two N atoms (N12 and N12D) from two different dib molecules with an N12–Co2–N12D bond angle of 174.78(10)° (Table ).
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

Complex [Co2(OA)(dib)2(H2O)] (1)

Complex 1 crystallizes in monoclinic C2/c space group. As shown in Figure a, there are two unique Co(II) atoms in the asymmetric unit of 1. Co1 sitting on an inversion center is six-coordinated with slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry by four O atoms (O3 and O4, O3A and O4A) from two different OA4- ligands and two N atoms (N42B and N42C) from two dib ligands, while the Co2 atom is five-coordinated and resides in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal environment. Two O atoms (O5 and O5D) from OA4- and O6 from a coordinated water molecule form the equatorial plane, and the axial positions are occupied by two N atoms (N12 and N12D) from two different dib molecules with an N12-Co2-N12D bond angle of 174.78(10)° (Table ).

(b) 1D double-chain structure linked by OA4– ligands and Co(II) centers. (c) 2D network in the ac plane illustrating π–π interactions between adjacent dib ligands indicated by dashed lines.

elements.content: Two neighboring Co2 ions are first connected by 4- and 4′-carboxylate groups from OA4– ligands to generate a one-dimensional (1D) chain structure, and the 3- and 4-COO– from adjacent chains chelate Co1 centers to feature a 1D double-chain (Figure b). Thus, the Co(II) atoms are bridged by carboxylate to form an infinite −(Co–O–C-O) n - chain in 1. As illustrated in Figure c, the neighboring 1D double-chains are further linked by pillar-like dib molecules to form a two-dimensional (2D) network in the ac plane. It is noteworthy that there are two types of π–π interactions between the adjacent benzene planes of dib ligands with d = 3.57 Å, θ = 6.0°, and d = 4.04 Å, θ = 0°, respectively (d stands for the centroid–centroid distance, and θ is the dihedral angle between two benzene ring planes). The result herein showed that π–π interactions play an important role in directing and consolidating the coordination structures. In addition, the 2D layers are joined together through O–H---O and C–H---O hydrogen bonds to form a three-dimensional (3D) packing diagram ().

elements.content: When another imidazole-containing ligand bbi with flexible -(CH2)4- spacers, instead of dib, was introduced into the reaction system, complex 2 with a different 2D structure was isolated. The crystallographic data showed that the asymmetric unit of 2 consists of two unique Co(II) ions, one OA4– ligand, two bbi ligands, and three solvent water molecules. As depicted in Figure a, Co1 and Co2 are both four coordinated with a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment by two O atoms (O2 and O7A for Co1, O5C and O9A for Co2) from OA4– ligands and two N atoms (N12 and N32B for Co1 and N22 and N42 for Co2) from bbi molecules. The Co–O and Co–N bond lengths are in the normal range as listed in Table .

Crystal Structure of [Co2(OA)(bbi)2]⋅3H2O (2)

When another imidazole-containing ligand bbi with flexible -(CH2)4- spacers, instead of dib, was introduced into the reaction system, complex 2 with a different 2D structure was isolated. The crystallographic data showed that the asymmetric unit of 2 consists of two unique Co(II) ions, one OA4- ligand, two bbi ligands, and three solvent water molecules. As depicted in Figure a, Co1 and Co2 are both four coordinated with a distorted tetrahedral coordination environment by two O atoms (O2 and O7A for Co1, O5C and O9A for Co2) from OA4- ligands and two N atoms (N12 and N32B for Co1 and N22 and N42 for Co2) from bbi molecules. The Co-O and Co-N bond lengths are in the normal range as listed in Table .

elements.content: If the connections through bbi ligands are temporarily ignored, each OA4– ligand adopts a μ4-bridging fashion with each of the four carboxylate groups in μ1-η1:η0 monodentate mode and links four Co(II) ions to generate a 2D double-layer network in the ac plane (Figure b,d). On the other hand, two bbi molecules adopt different conformations of GGT and GTG in the asymmetric unit, and link the Co(II) centers to feature two distinct left- and right-handed helical chains as shown in Figure c. The most striking feature of complex 2 is that these two types of homochiral helical chains are alternatively filled in the cavities of 2D double-layer network constructed by OA4– ligands and Co(II) centers (Figure d). Similar to 1, two O–H---O and nine C–H---O hydrogen bonds further link adjacent 2D layers into a 3D structure (), which indicates again that the weak interactions such as hydrogen bonding can have a positive effect on the final architectures of coordination polymers.

elements.content: As the pyridyl-containing N-donor bridging ligand bpe was taken into reaction, complex 3 with an entirely different structure was obtained. It is interesting to find out that the 3′-carboxylate group remains protonated and is free of coordination, which can be confirmed by the observation of a vibration band at 1728 cm–1 in the IR spectrum (see ). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 3 is a 3D metal–organic framework with (64.82)(66) topology. As depicted in Figure a, there are two crystallographically independent Co(II) ions in the asymmetric unit. Co1 is six-coordinated and resides at the center of a slightly distorted octahedral environment. Four O atoms (O1, O3, O2B, and O1W) from two HOA3– ligands and one water molecule are in planar positions with Co–O bond lengths ranging from 2.088(3) to 2.144(3) Å, while the axial positions are occupied by two N atoms (N1 and N2A) from different bpe bridging ligands with an N1–Co1–N2A bond angle of 175.16(15)°. Co2 sitting on an inversion center is also six-coordinated in an octahedral geometry by two O atoms (O6 and O6C) from HOA3– ligands and four other O atoms (O2W, O3W, O2WC, and O3WC) from coordinated water molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Co3(HOA)2(bpe)2(H2O)6]⋅2H2O (3)

As the pyridyl-containing N-donor bridging ligand bpe was taken into reaction, complex 3 with an entirely different structure was obtained. It is interesting to find out that the 3'-carboxylate group remains protonated and is free of coordination, which can be confirmed by the observation of a vibration band at 1728 cm-1 in the IR spectrum (see ). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that 3 is a 3D metal-organic framework with (64.82)(66) topology. As depicted in Figure a, there are two crystallographically independent Co(II) ions in the asymmetric unit. Co1 is six-coordinated and resides at the center of a slightly distorted octahedral environment. Four O atoms (O1, O3, O2B, and O1W) from two HOA3- ligands and one water molecule are in planar positions with Co-O bond lengths ranging from 2.088(3) to 2.144(3) Å, while the axial positions are occupied by two N atoms (N1 and N2A) from different bpe bridging ligands with an N1-Co1-N2A bond angle of 175.16(15)°. Co2 sitting on an inversion center is also six-coordinated in an octahedral geometry by two O atoms (O6 and O6C) from HOA3- ligands and four other O atoms (O2W, O3W, O2WC, and O3WC) from coordinated water molecules.

elements.content: In complex 3, 3- and 4-carboxylate groups show μ2-η1:η1 bridging mode in syn-anti conformation and μ1 -η1:η0 monodentate mode, respectively, and link the neighboring Co1 centers to form a 1D chain structure. As shown in Figure b, adjacent 1D chains are further linked into a 2D network by coordination of 4′-COO– from HOA3– ligands to Co2 ions, which contains 62-membered rings with the window of 29.23 × 8.35 Å. Further, the 2D layers are connected in ABAB fashion by rod-like bpe bridging ligands to form a 3D architecture (Figure c). Meanwhile, C–H---O and O–H---O hydrogen bonds further consolidate the 3D framework of 3. If the two HOA3– ligands linked by Co2 ion are viewed as one node, it connects four Co1 centers (). In turn, Co1 centers can also be considered as four-connected nodes, linked by two HOA3– nodes and two bpe molecules, respectively (). Therefore, the 3D structure of 3 could be assigned as (64.82)(66) topology (Figure d).

elements.content: When a rigid pyridyl-containing bridging ligand dpe was introduced, complex 4 with a different 3D structure was generated. The structure of 4 was determined by X-ray single crystallographic analysis, and the result revealed that 4 crystallizes in monoclinic form with space group P21 /c. As shown in Figure a, there are two unique Co(II) centers with similar coordination geometries, one OA4–, one centrosymmetric dpe, and two coordinated water molecules in an asymmetric unit. Co1 and Co2 are both in an octahedral coordination environment. Three O atoms (O2, O6 and O4A for Co1, and O1, O2 and O8 for Co2) from two different OA4– ligands and one N atom (N1 for Co1, and N2 for Co2) from a dpe molecule are in an equatorial plane, and the axial positions are occupied by one O atom from OA4– (O3 for Co1, and O6 for Co2) and a coordinated water molecule (O1W for Co1, and O2W for Co2).
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Co2(OA)(dpe)(H2O)2] (4)

When a rigid pyridyl-containing bridging ligand dpe was introduced, complex 4 with a different 3D structure was generated. The structure of 4 was determined by X-ray single crystallographic analysis, and the result revealed that 4 crystallizes in monoclinic form with space group P21 /c. As shown in Figure a, there are two unique Co(II) centers with similar coordination geometries, one OA4-, one centrosymmetric dpe, and two coordinated water molecules in an asymmetric unit. Co1 and Co2 are both in an octahedral coordination environment. Three O atoms (O2, O6 and O4A for Co1, and O1, O2 and O8 for Co2) from two different OA4- ligands and one N atom (N1 for Co1, and N2 for Co2) from a dpe molecule are in an equatorial plane, and the axial positions are occupied by one O atom from OA4- (O3 for Co1, and O6 for Co2) and a coordinated water molecule (O1W for Co1, and O2W for Co2).

elements.content: Interestingly, Co1 and Co2 are linked by two O atoms from 4- and 4′-carboxylate groups to generate a Co2 unit with a Co–Co distance of 3.40 Å, which is further connected by a 3-carboxylate group to form an infinite 1D chain (Figure b). To the best of our knowledge, this kind of Co(II) chain has not been reported in previous studies. As illustrated in Figure c, connection of a 1D Co(II) chain via OA4– ligands in the bc plane leads to a 2D network containing a 11.19 × 7.50 Å window, which is occupied by dpe molecules through N1–Co1 coordination bonds. Further, another type of dpe molecule joins Co2 atoms from adjacent 2D layers to result in a 3D framework of 4, in which hydrogen bonds consolidate the structure (Figure d). In 4, one OA4– ligand connects three Co2 units, and one Co2 unit is in turn linked by three OA4– ligands (), and further connections through pillar-like dpe molecules generates a 3D framework with (44,66) topology (Figure e).

To the best of our knowledge, this kind of Co(II) chain has not been reported in previous studies. As illustrated in Figure c, connection of a 1D Co(II) chain via OA4- ligands in the bc plane leads to a 2D network containing a 11.19 × 7.50 Å window, which is occupied by dpe molecules through N1-Co1 coordination bonds. Further, another type of dpe molecule joins Co2 atoms from adjacent 2D layers to result in a 3D framework of 4, in which hydrogen bonds consolidate the structure (Figure d). In 4, one OA4- ligand connects three Co2 units, and one Co2 unit is in turn linked by three OA4- ligands (), and further connections through pillar-like dpe molecules generates a 3D framework with (44,66) topology (Figure e).

elements.content: Thermalgravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed to verify the thermal stability of the complexes, and the results are shown in . Complex 1 slowly lost a weight of 2.05% up to around 300 °C (calcd 2.00%) due to the loss of coordinated water molecules, and then the framework began to decompose. A total loss of 5.83% was observed for 2 in the temperature range of 50–155 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd 6.04%), and the decomposition of the residue was observed at about 305 °C. As to 3, a weight loss of 10.32% was observed in the temperature range of 145–210 °C, which corresponds to the release of both the coordinated and uncoordinated water molecules (calcd 10.48%), and then the framework was found to decompose upon further heating. Complex 4 was stable up to 175 °C, and then a weight loss of 5.15% was found between 175 to 210 °C, which is in agreement with the departure of two coordinated water molecules (calcd 5.31%) and further weight loss was observed at about 335 °C.

Thermalgravimetric Analyses

Thermalgravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed to verify the thermal stability of the complexes, and the results are shown in . Complex 1 slowly lost a weight of 2.05% up to around 300 °C (calcd 2.00%) due to the loss of coordinated water molecules, and then the framework began to decompose. A total loss of 5.83% was observed for 2 in the temperature range of 50-155 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd 6.04%), and the decomposition of the residue was observed at about 305 °C. As to 3, a weight loss of 10.32% was observed in the temperature range of 145-210 °C, which corresponds to the release of both the coordinated and uncoordinated water molecules (calcd 10.48%), and then the framework was found to decompose upon further heating. Complex 4 was stable up to 175 °C, and then a weight loss of 5.15% was found between 175 to 210 °C, which is in agreement with the departure of two coordinated water molecules (calcd 5.31%) and further weight loss was observed at about 335 °C.

elements.content: From the crystal structure as described above, magnetic interactions between the Co(II) atoms bridged by carboxylate groups in 1, 3, and 4 may be expected, while in complex 2 the Co(II) atoms are linked together through the OA4– and bbi ligands and no magnetic interactions can be expected. Thus, temperature -dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements of complexes 1, 3, and 4 were carried out on a crystalline sample in the range of 1.8–300 K in 2000 Oe.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

From the crystal structure as described above, magnetic interactions between the Co(II) atoms bridged by carboxylate groups in 1, 3, and 4 may be expected, while in complex 2 the Co(II) atoms are linked together through the OA4- and bbi ligands and no magnetic interactions can be expected. Thus, temperature -dependent magnetic susceptibility measurements of complexes 1, 3, and 4 were carried out on a crystalline sample in the range of 1.8-300 K in 2000 Oe.

elements.content: As it is known, the magnetic analysis for the Co(II) complexes is rather complicated because of its spin–orbital coupling, and some approximate methods are applied to analyze the magnetic interactions between the Co(II) ions. The plots of χM T vs T and χM –1 vs T for complex 1 are displayed in Figure . At 300 K, the χM T value is 2.74 cm3 K mol–1, which is significantly larger than the spin-only value of 1.875 cm3 K mol–1 for mononuclear Co(II) ion (g = 2, s = 3/2), ascribing to the contribution of Co(II) ions. Fitting the data above 30 K using the Curie–Weiss Law, χM = C/(T – θ), yields a Curie constant C = 2.92 cm3 K mol–1 and a negative Weiss constant θ of −20.76 K. At first glance, this kind of behavior of χM T and the negative θ value might indicate a dominant antiferromagnetic coupling between the metal centers. However, spin–orbit coupling, which itself can lead to a negative θ value and a decrease of χM T at high temperature, is remarkable for the 4T1g state of Co(II) ions in an octahedral ligand field. Therefore, the slight increase of χM T below 2.5 K might indicate that the ferromagnetic coupling between Co(II) ions occurs in this system and is strong enough to compensate for the single-ion behavior resulting from spin–orbital coupling. According to previous reports, a preliminary fitting of the susceptibility data was carried out by considering a mononuclear Co(II) ion with spin–orbit coupling parameter λ (H = −λLS) in a molecular field approximation. The χmono for a mononuclear Co(II) in an octahedral environment can be calculated from eq with x = λ/k B T. The parameter A gives a measure of the crystal field strength relative to the interelectronic repulsions and is equal to 1.5 for a weak crystal field, 1.32 for a free ion, and 1.0 for a strong field. χ m o n o = 1 T × { 7 ( 3 − A ) 2 x 5 + 12 ( 2 + A ) 2 25 A + [ 2 ( 11 − 2 A ) 2 x 45 + 176 ( 2 + A ) 2 675 A ] exp ( − 5 A x 2 ) + [ ( 5 + A ) 2 x 9 − 20 ( 2 + 2 A ) 2 27 A ] exp ( − 4 A x ) } / { 8 x 3 [ 3 + 2 exp ( − 5 A x 2 ) + exp ( − 4 A x ) ] }

elements.content: The magnetic behavior of complex 4 was also investigated, and the results are illustrated in Figure . The measured χM T value at 300 K equals 6.24 cm3 K mol–1, which is significantly larger than the spin only value of 3.75 cm3 K mol–1 for two uncoupled spins (g = 2.0 and s = 3/2). Upon lowering the temperature, χM T continuously decreases and reaches a minimum of 3.25 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K. The feature might be caused by antiferromagnetic exchange interactions as well as the effect of spin–orbit coupling. In this case, in order to obtain an estimate of the strength of the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction, a simple phenomenological eq was carried out according to Rabu and co-workers’ reports. χ T = A exp ( − E 1 / k T ) + B exp ( − E 2 / k T )

The best fit of the experimental data gives that A + B = 6.75 cm3 K mol–1, E 1/k = +64.35 K, and –E 2/k = −0.53 K respectively. According to the Ising chain approximation [χT ∝ exp(+J/2kT)], we can get J = −1.06, although weak indeed, which in turn confirmed the antiferromagnetic exchange interaction between metal ions in complex 4.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized four novel cobalt(II) coordination polymers with a flexible 3,3′,4,4′-oxidiphthalic acid (H4OA) and a series of N-donor bridging ligands through hydrothermal reactions. The results of this work further demonstrate that the mixed ligand strategy is effective for construction of coordination frameworks with interesting structures and properties.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized four novel cobalt(II) coordination polymers with a flexible 3,3',4,4'-oxidiphthalic acid (H4OA) and a series of N-donor bridging ligands through hydrothermal reactions. The results of this work further demonstrate that the mixed ligand strategy is effective for construction of coordination frameworks with interesting structures and properties.

This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

A mixture containing Co(NO3)2·6H2O (58.2 mg, 0.2 mmol), H4OA (34.6 mg, 0.1 mmol), dib (21.0 mg, 0.1 mmol), and NaOH (16.0 mg, 0.4 mmol) dissolved in 8 mL of H2O was sealed in a 16 mL Teflon lined stainless steel container and heated at 140 °C for 3 days. Pink block crystals of 1 were collected by filtration and washed by water and ethanol several times with a yield of 76%. Anal. Calcd. for C40H28Co2N8O10: C 53.47; H 3.14; N 12.47; found: C 53.38; H 3.26; N 12.43%. cln_elements.content:
Thermalgravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed to verify the thermal stability of the complexes, and the results are shown in . Complex 1 slowly lost a weight of 2.05% up to around 300 °C (calcd 2.00%) due to the loss of coordinated water molecules, and then the framework began to decompose. A total loss of 5.83% was observed for 2 in the temperature range of 50–155 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of lattice water molecules (calcd 6.04%), and the decomposition of the residue was observed at about 305 °C. As to 3, a weight loss of 10.32% was observed in the temperature range of 145–210 °C, which corresponds to the release of both the coordinated and uncoordinated water molecules (calcd 10.48%), and then the framework was found to decompose upon further heating. Complex 4 was stable up to 175 °C, and then a weight loss of 5.15% was found between 175 to 210 °C, which is in agreement with the departure of two coordinated water molecules (calcd 5.31%) and further weight loss was observed at about 335 °C.

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibility of complex 3 is similar to 1 owing to their similar metal connection modes. As shown in Figure , at 300 K, the χM T value equals 3.21 cm3 K mol–1, and after decreasing upon cooling to a minimum of 1.98 cm3 K mol–1 at 3.5 K, it increases to 2.02 cm3 K mol–1 at 1.8 K. The data between 30 and 300 K are fitted by the Curie–Weiss Law and gives C = 3.28 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −15.76 K. As discussed for 1, the negative θ value does not necessarily stand for antiferromagnetic coupling because of the existence of strong spin–orbit coupling for Co(II) ions. In this case, similar to 1, eqs and are used to fit the χM T data above 30 K. As a result, it yields λ = −143 cm–1, A = 1.29, zJ = 1.55 cm–1, and g = 2.51 with R = 8.6 × 10–4. Herein, the positive zJ value shows again the ferromagnetic coupling between Co(II) ions.
